唐纳德·特朗普的儿子小唐纳德·特朗普将于周四第二天就该家族公司的财务报表作证，纽约法官 裁定该公司的财务报表存在欺诈性夸大，以误导贷方和保险公司。

小唐纳德是准备在纽约民事欺诈审判中出庭作证的四名家庭成员之一，这可能会阻碍他父亲在从政之前建立了商业大亨声誉的房地产帝国。

这位美国前总统将于周一作证，这是 2024 年共和党总统提名领跑者多次出庭作证的最新一次。

纽约州总检察长利蒂西亚·詹姆斯 (Letitia James) 正在寻求至少 2.5 亿美元的赔偿，并永久禁止特朗普、小唐纳德及其儿子埃里克在该州经营企业。

法官阿瑟·恩戈伦 (Arthur Engoron) 已经裁定，三名被告和该公司欺诈性地夸大了战利品和其他资产的价值，以赢得有利的融资条件。

恩戈隆已下令解散控制特朗普房地产投资组合支柱的公司，其中包括曼哈顿的特朗普大厦。在特朗普上诉期间，这项裁决被搁置。

在周三的证词中，小唐纳德试图尽量减少自己对公司财务报表的参与，称这些报表主要是由公司会计师准备的。

他在法庭上时不时地用自嘲的俏皮话来引来笑声，说自己缺乏经济头脑，这与他作为父亲的政治攻击狗所培养的尖锐性格形成鲜明对比。

此次审判是唐纳德·特朗普在竞选夺回白宫时必须应对的众多法律麻烦之一。他在四项单独的刑事起诉中面临总共 91 项重罪指控，其中两起案件源于他试图推翻 2020 年选举失败的结果。

尽管如此，在 2024 年 11 月大选中与民主党总统乔·拜登对决的共和党总统提名中，特朗普仍遥遥领先于竞争对手。

特朗普否认在所有刑事和民事案件中存在不当行为，并指责詹姆斯和恩戈隆存在政治偏见。

他并未因这些袭击而受到制裁，但恩戈隆因两次违反禁止他公开谈论法庭工作人员的有限禁言令而对他处以 15,000 美元的罚款。

他还因华盛顿 联邦选举颠覆审判而受到有限禁言令。特朗普声称两者都侵犯了他的言论自由权。

照片中，这名妇女怀里抱着一个孩子，在膝盖上保持平衡。这是一个引起共鸣的形象，与人类历史一样古老。

但与熟悉的情况相反，我们看到她抱在怀里的孩子是一具裹着裹尸布的尸体。这是一个充满强烈悲伤的安静时刻。女子戴着头巾，低着头。我们看不到她是谁，也无法了解关于这个孩子的任何信息——即使它是男孩还是女孩。

这个孩子是以色列-哈马斯战争中双方丧生的众多人之一。大多数人的名字我们永远不会知道，他们的去世将为我们永远不会见面的家人带来终生的悲伤。据联合国儿童基金会称，在 21 世纪，世界各地平均每天有近 20 名儿童在战争中丧生或致残。

10 月 17 日，路透社摄影师穆罕默德·萨勒姆 (Mohammad Salem) 在加沙地带南部汗尤尼斯 (Khan Younis) 的纳赛尔医院太平间，那里的居民正在寻找失踪的亲人。

他看到太平间里，女人蹲在地上，抽泣着，紧紧地抱住孩子的尸体。

“这是一个强大而悲伤的时刻，我觉得这张照片概括了加沙地带正在发生的事情的更广泛意义，”他说。 “人们很困惑，从一个地方跑到另一个地方，急切地想知道亲人的命运，这个女人引起了我的注意，因为她抱着小女孩的尸体，不肯放手。”

这一刻对塞勒姆来说尤其令人心酸，他的妻子几天前刚刚生下了自己的孩子。

在通讯中断的加沙，寻人之路充满困难。但照片拍摄两周后，路透社找到了照片中的女子，并在她位于汗尤尼斯的家中采访了她。

她叫 Inas Abu Maamar，照片中她抱着的尸体是她 5 岁的侄女 Saly。

当伊纳斯听说她叔叔的房子被击中时，她赶紧跑到了停尸房。

“当我看到这个女孩时，我失去了良心，我把她抱在怀里，”她说。 “医生让我放手……但我告诉他们把她留给我。”

萨莉的母亲和妹妹以及伊纳斯的叔叔和婶婶也被杀。萨莉是伊纳斯的最爱，她常常在去幼儿园的路上顺便去她祖母家，请她的姑妈给她拍照。

“我手机里的大部分视频和照片都是她的，”伊内斯说。

袭击发生时，萨利 4 岁的弟弟艾哈迈德 (Ahmed) 正在屋外，幸免于难。他现在和伊纳斯住在一起。但伊纳斯说，他对比赛没什么兴趣。他很少说话，除了询问他的妹妹莎莉在哪里。

据黎巴嫩国家通讯社（NNA）报道，周四在边境附近地区发现了两名被以色列军队枪杀的黎巴嫩牧羊人的尸体。

以色列军方发言人表示正在调查该报告。

NNA 没有透露其报道的来源，但称他们在瓦扎尼河附近放牧羊群时遭到枪击。

黎巴嫩安全部门消息人士告诉路透社，来自黎巴嫩边境瓦扎尼村庄的牧羊人年龄分别为 20 岁和 21 岁。

在黎巴嫩南部行动的联合国维和部队联黎部队周三表示，黎巴嫩军队已请求其提供援助，以撤离瓦扎尼地区的两名受伤人员。

报道称，以色列军队暂停开火，以便黎巴嫩军队和联黎部队进行搜索，但由于黑暗和该地区存在地雷，搜索工作被推迟到周四早上。

黎巴嫩军队没有官方发言人，也没有立即发表声明。

自10月7日真主党盟友哈马斯与以色列爆发冲突以来，以色列军队和全副武装、伊朗支持的黎巴嫩真主党一直在边境交火。

俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京周四签署了一项法律，撤销俄罗斯对《全面禁止核试验条约》的批准，他表示此举旨在让莫斯科与美国保持一致。

俄罗斯表示，除非华盛顿恢复核试验，否则俄罗斯不会恢复核试验，而且取消批准不会改变其核态势或分享核活动信息的方式。

华盛顿签署但从未批准该 1996 年条约，普京表示，他希望签署并批准该条约的俄罗斯对该条约采取与美国相同的立场。

一些西方军控专家担心，俄罗斯可能正在逐步进行试验，以在乌克兰战争中进行恐吓和引发恐惧，但俄罗斯官员淡化了这一想法。

普京10月5日表示，在一些俄罗斯安全专家和议员呼吁测试核弹以向西方发出警告后，他还没有准备好表明俄罗斯是否应该恢复核试验。

西方专家担心，如果此举真的发生，可能会开启大国核试验的新时代。

普京对取消批准法的批准发布在政府网站上，并表示该决定立即生效。

俄罗斯议会参众两院已经批准了这一举措。

后苏联时代的俄罗斯从未进行过核试验。苏联上次试验是在1990年，美国是在1992年。

俄罗斯周四表示，摩尔多瓦亲欧洲总统马亚·桑杜是一种耻辱，并指责摩尔多瓦政府试图通过夸大俄罗斯的威胁来在地方选举前转移人们对自身失败的注意力。

桑杜谴责俄罗斯在乌克兰发动的战争，并指责莫斯科试图通过政变推翻她，她周三表示，俄罗斯正试图在本周末的地方选举中收买选民。

俄罗斯外交部发言人玛丽亚·扎哈罗娃对记者表示：“玛雅·桑杜是国家的耻辱，也是摩尔多瓦人民的主要威胁。”

扎哈罗娃表示，莫斯科正在密切关注选举前的局势，并指责摩尔多瓦政府试图利用俄罗斯夸大的威胁来转移人们对自身巨大缺陷的注意力。

扎哈罗娃说：“摩尔多瓦当局继续消除任何异议表现，并对政治对手进行镇压。”

十月，摩尔多瓦以“违宪”为由禁止亲俄反对派肖尔党，此举遭到俄罗斯批评。

扎哈罗娃表示，六名俄罗斯选举监督员以及俄罗斯驻摩尔多瓦大使馆的工作人员被拒绝参加选举。

盖伊·福尔肯布里奇编辑; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 09:53:49 GMT QBZR543MC5NGJBAREZKCTY6DSM https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ Russia-says-moldovas-president-is-disgrace-2023-11-02/Reuters俄罗斯摩尔多瓦/选举（更新 1） Israeli army battles Hamas fighters in drive towards Gaza CitySummary:
  • 最新进展：
  • 巴勒斯坦医务人员称，以色列军队在约旦河西岸的炮火造成三名青少年死亡。以色列军方和医务人员称，巴勒斯坦枪手杀死了一名以色列司机。

周四，以色列坦克和军队向加沙城推进，但遭到哈马斯武装分子的猛烈抵抗，他们使用迫击炮和隧道内的打了就跑的袭击，近四个星期的轰炸造成巴勒斯坦人死亡人数不断增加。

在被围困飞地的南端，持有外国护照的人被允许通过拉法过境点进入埃及。

战争正在逼近加沙地带北部的主要人口中心，那里是伊斯兰组织的根据地，以色列一直要求人们离开那里，并发誓要一劳永逸地消灭哈马斯。

“我们已经到了加沙城的门口，”以色列军事指挥官伊齐克·科恩准将说。

居民们表示，哈马斯及其盟友伊斯兰圣战组织的战士从隧道中出现，向坦克开火，然后又消失在网络中，两个组织的视频显示，这是针对一支强大得多的军队的游击式行动。

“他们整晚都没有停止对加沙城的轰炸，房子也没有停止震动，”一名住在当地的男子说道，他要求不透露姓名。 “但到了早上，我们发现以色列军队仍然在城外的郊区，这意味着抵抗力量比他们预期的要严重。”

以色列军官强调了在城市环境中作战的困难。目前该战略似乎是将大量部队集中在加沙地带北部，而不是对整个领土发动地面攻击。

这场 长达数十年的冲突中的最新一场战争始于 10 月 7 日哈马斯武装分子突破边境。以色列称，这是以色列 75 年历史上伤亡最惨重的一天，他们杀害了 1,400 人，其中大部分是平民，并劫持了 200 多名人质。

据加沙卫生当局称，以色列随后对这片拥有 230 万人口的巴勒斯坦小飞地进行轰炸，已造成至少 8,796 人死亡，其中包括 3,648 名儿童。

尽管西方国家，尤其是美国历来支持以色列，但瓦砾中尸体的悲惨景象和加沙境内地狱般的环境引发了世界各地克制的呼吁和街头抗议。

然而，以色列右翼总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡知道，他的职业生涯和遗产取决于镇压哈马斯。

“哈马斯已经做好充分准备”

居民报告说，加沙城周围地区整个晚上都发生迫击炮弹袭击，并表示以色列坦克和推土机有时会在瓦砾上行驶并推倒建筑物，而不是使用普通道路，因为飞机从头顶上轰炸。

以色列军事工程师首席伊多·米兹拉希准将告诉陆军广播电台，部队正处于开放加沙通道的第一阶段。他说：“这片地区肯定比过去布满了更多的雷区和诱杀装置。” “哈马斯已经学习并做好了充分准备。”

加沙全面封锁三周多后， 外国护照持有者和一些重伤员被允许出境。巴勒斯坦边境官员瓦埃尔·阿布·梅森 (Wael Abu Mehsen) 表示，继周三至少有 320 名外国公民之后，周四将有 400 名外国公民通过拉法过境点前往埃及。

梅森补充说，另外 60 名重伤的巴勒斯坦人也将穿越边境。

以色列最近的空袭包括人口稠密的贾巴利亚地区，该地区于 1948 年被设立为难民营。

加沙哈马斯媒体办公室表示，周二和周三的两次袭击中至少有 195 名巴勒斯坦人丧生，120 人失踪，至少 777 人受伤。

“这是一场屠杀，”现场的一名人士说道，人们正在拼命寻找被困的受害者。

以色列指责哈马斯躲在平民背后，并表示在贾巴利亚杀害了两名哈马斯军事领导人。

随着阿拉伯国家对以色列行为的愤怒日益强烈，联合国人权事务高级专员也对以色列的“不成比例的袭击……可能构成战争罪”表示担忧。

以色列军方周四表示，另一名士兵在加沙战斗中死亡，自周五扩大地面行动以来，死亡人数达到 17 人。

声明补充说，军队已经杀死了“数十名恐怖分子”。

暴力事件也蔓延到被占领的约旦河西岸，以色列为逮捕可疑武装分子而进行军事突袭，引发了与枪手和投掷石块的人们的对抗。

巴勒斯坦医务人员表示，周四早些时候，三名青少年在以色列军队的炮火中丧生。以色列军方发言人没有立即发表评论。

另外，军方和医务人员表示，巴勒斯坦枪手在约旦河西岸杀害了一名以色列司机。巴勒斯坦各派没有立即对此提出要求。

“我们睁开眼睛观察死人”

由于国际社会呼吁“人道主义暂停”敌对行动无人理睬，加沙的局势十分严峻，食品、燃料、饮用水和药品都短缺。

“我们对死者睁开眼睛，对死者闭上眼睛，”周三等待进入埃及的美国护照持有者法蒂·阿布·哈桑博士说。

医院，包括加沙唯一的癌症医院，由于燃料短缺而陷入困境。以色列拒绝让人道主义车队携带燃料，理由是担心哈马斯武装分子会将其转作军事用途。

加沙卫生部发言人阿什拉夫·库德拉表示， 印度尼西亚医院的主发电机已不再运行。

医院正在改用备用发电机，但无法再为太平间冰箱和制氧机供电。 “如果我们在接下来的几天内得不到燃料，我们将不可避免地陷入灾难，”他说。

美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯定于周四启程，开始不到一个月的时间第三次访问以色列。

他的发言人说，他计划周五会见内塔尼亚胡，表达对其亲密盟友的声援，同时重申需要尽量减少巴勒斯坦平民伤亡。

Reporting by Jonathan Spicer and Ezgi Erkoyun; Editing by Alison Williams and Miral Fahmy ; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 09:13:03 GMT GKGSO2UESFNHFBZZGQFBYNFZGU https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/turkey-detains-alleged-drug-kingpin-organised-crime-bust-2023-11-02/Reuters TURKEY CRIME/AUSTRALIA USA (UPDATE 1) Activists struggle to commemorate victims of Soviet repression

If history is written by the victors, then a small group of Russian activists are doing their best to make sure the battle to remember the millions of victims of Soviet repression is not lost - one small steel plaque at a time.

President Vladimir Putin has sidelined those who have done most to research the crimes of seven decades of communism, perhaps loath to invite comparison with his own suppression of dissent, or blur the patriotism needed to drive his war in Ukraine.

The leading chronicler, Memorial International , was banned almost two years ago after more than three decades of painstaking work.

But the Last Address project has over several years managed to put up 1,200 plaques on buildings across Russia, each memorialising one victim at their last home before they were executed or exiled, or left to rot in a prison colony.

Each steel rectangle, 19 cm by 11, has a square hole, and is engraved with only the person's name and profession and their dates of arrest, internment or execution, and formal rehabilitation.

"Every plaque has been requested by someone. We don't invent names ... The Last Address memorial project is based on public initiative," said Mikhail Sheynker, 75, a coordinator in Moscow.

Sometimes local people resent the plaques, at odds with the prevailing official patriotism, or say they are turning the city into a cemetery.

"People who talk about cemeteries forget that our heroes don't have their own grave," Sheynker counters. "They're all buried in mass graves."

MEMORIAL PLAQUES REMOVED, AND SOMETIMES REPLACED

Yevgeniya Kulakova, Last Address coordinator in St Petersburg, said 434 plaques had been installed there since 2015, always with the building owner's permission.

At least 45 have been secretly removed. But some, like a plaque on Vasilievsky Island, have also secretly returned.

"It hung there for a day, then someone took it down, no one knows who. A week later this replica appeared. Another week later, someone put the original removed plaque next to it," Kulakova said.

"Who took down the sign? Who made the duplicate? We don't know any of that. But it means that the project is alive. That is, there are people who want to protect them (the plaques), even though there are people who are against them."

Mikhail Polenov, whose grandfather has a plaque, feels the latter are gaining ground.

"Those people who don't need the memory, they're in fashion now," he said.

His maternal grandfather, career soldier Alexei Peremytov, was shot on July 28, 1937, one of thousands accused of espionage and conspiracy at the height of Joseph Stalin's purges, the "Great Terror".

Polenov has researched the case since 1989, and is grateful to Last Address.

Attending another unveiling last year, he found they were also replacing his grandfather's plaque, which had been removed without his knowledge.

"They hadn't told me anything because they felt sorry for me. Because when I found out, I nearly collapsed."

Artist Vladimir Ovchinnikov , 85, had hoped to see a Museum of Political Repression adorned with dozens of his portraits of victims open on Oct. 29, the Day of Remembrance of the Victims of Political Repression, in Borovsk, 115 km southwest of Moscow. But local authorities cancelled the event.

It was not the first time Ovchinnikov, whose grandfather was shot by Lenin's Bolsheviks in 1919 and whose father was arrested during Stalin's purges, had been thwarted in this way.

"Why do we stay silent? Why do we hide things?"他说。 "Instead of learning lessons, we're creating a country of lessons not learned."

Pakistan's northwestern border crossing was flooded with thousands of people looking to cross into Afghanistan on Thursday, a day after the government's deadline expired for undocumented foreigners to leave or face expulsion.

Pakistani authorities had begun rounding up undocumented foreigners , most of them Afghans, hours before the deadline. More than a million Afghans could have to leave Pakistan or face arrest and forcible expulsion as a result of the directive that Islamabad delivered abruptly a month ago.

The Pakistan government said Afghans had been involved in militant attacks and crime in the country and has brushed off calls from the United Nations, rights groups and Western embassies to reconsider its expulsion plan.

More than 24,000 Afghans crossed into Afghanistan using the Torkham border crossing on Wednesday alone, Deputy Commissioner Khyber Tribal District Abdul Nasir Khan told Reuters.

"There were a large number waiting for clearance and we made extra arrangements to better facilitate the clearance process," he said.

Khan said authorities had worked well into the night at a camp set up near the crossing. The border is usually closed by sundown.

He said 128,000 Afghan nationals have left for Afghanistan through the border crossing since the Pakistan government gave its ultimatum, and thousands more are expected to cross in coming days.

Pakistan authorities have barred media access to the border crossing since Tuesday.

Some Afghans who have been ordered to leave have spent decades in Pakistan , while some have never been to Afghanistan, and wondering how they can start a new life there.

Liz Lee、Xiaoyu Yin、北京新闻编辑室报道；克里斯蒂安·施莫林格编辑; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 07:17:00 GMT ENSRBIKGZJPBTNRFROJF3HM6MI https://www.reuters.com/world/china/china-lowers-flags-half-mast-former-premier-lis-cremation-day-2023-11-02/Liz Lee, Xiaoyu Yin中国政治/Likeqiang（更新 1，电视，PIX） Israeli settler attacks fuel the fire as Gaza war ragesSummary:
  • 121 West Bank Palestinians killed since Hamas attack
  • Increasing West Bank settler violence worries Israel allies
  • Father and son killed at funeral for three shot by settlers

Mourning his father and brother, Mohammed Wadi says armed Israeli settlers from outposts overlooking his olive-growing West Bank village no longer aim low when they shoot at Palestinian neighbours. "Now, they shoot to kill," he said.

Violence in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, already at a more than 15-year high this year, surged further after Israel hurtled into a new war in the separate enclave of Gaza in response to Palestinian militant group Hamas unleashing the deadliest day in Israel's history on Oct. 7.

Days later, on Oct. 12, Wadi's father and brother were shot dead when armed Israeli settlers and soldiers stopped a funeral cortege for three other Palestinians killed by settlers the day before, two Reuters witnesses and three other people present said. It was one of the more than 170 attacks on Palestinians involving settlers recorded by the UN since the Hamas rampage.

"Arabs and Jews used to throw stones at each other. Settlers my age now all seem to have automatic weapons," said Wadi, 29, in the olive-growing village of Qusra. And while a decade ago armed settlers would fire their weapons to scare or injure villagers during confrontations, increasingly, shootings were deadly, he said.

Reuters could not definitively establish who shot the Wadis. Palestinian officials who investigated the funeral killings said the gunfire appeared to come from settlers rather than soldiers, a view supported by the three other people present.

Shira Liebman, head of the Yesha Council, the main West Bank settlers organisation, told Reuters that settlers were not involved in the killings and were not targeting Palestinians.

Israel's hard-right National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir, one of at least two senior government ministers living in the settlements, said he had ordered the purchase of 10,000 rifles to arm Israeli civilians, including settlers, after Hamas' attack.

Ben-Gvir's office did not respond to a request for comment about whether guns had already been distributed in the West Bank. He said on Twitter on Oct. 11 that 900 assault rifles had been handed out in areas to the north of the West Bank, close to Lebanon, and that thousands more would soon be distributed.

Vigilante-style settler attacks have killed 29 people this year according to the UN Humanitarian Affairs Office, OCHA. At least eight of those were since Oct 7. alone, worrying ordinary Palestinians, Israeli security experts and Western officials.

Washington has condemned settler attacks on Palestinians in the West Bank while the European Union on Tuesday denounced "settler terrorism" that risked a "dangerous escalation of the conflict."

Daily settler attacks have more than doubled, the UN figures show, since Hamas, which controls the coastal enclave of Gaza to Israel's southwest, killed 1,400 Israelis and took more than 200 hostage. Israel has since bombed and invaded Gaza, killing nearly 9,000 Palestinians.

While Hamas tightly controls besieged Gaza, the West Bank is a complex patchwork of hillside cities, Israeli settlements and army checkpoints that split Palestinian communities.

Hamas cited Israeli actions in the West Bank, core to a would-be Palestinian state, in waging its killing spree.

FUNERAL KILLINGS

After settlers shot dead three Palestinians at an olive grove near Qusra on Oct. 11, Mohammed's brother Ahmed and father Ibrahim saw it as their duty to greet the funeral procession as it brought the bodies back from a nearby hospital, he said.

Wadi's father was shot through the torso, his brother through the neck and chest, after the armed settlers, in the presence of uniformed soldiers, blocked the cortege at a roadside, the five witnesses said.

"It was gunfire from settlers," Abdullah Abu Rahma, who works for the Palestinian government's Settlement and Wall Resistance Commission said.

The Israeli military said it tried to disperse clashes between Israelis and Palestinians on the day and that the incident was being investigated. Settlement official Liebman denied settler involvement in the killings, while one local Hebrew-language social media page that backs settler activists said the Israeli military had fired on the Wadis.

"We've had more than our share of brutal terrorist attacks. We're facing an enemy who wants to destroy us," settlement leader Liebman told Reuters, echoing widespread security fears among Israelis following the Hamas incursion.

Liebman said "local security teams" were equipped to protect Jewish communities.

Since the Oct. 7 rampage, visible support for Hamas has grown among Palestinians in the West Bank, including in areas where the Islamist group has not traditionally been strong.

This year was already the deadliest in at least 15 years for West Bank residents, with some 200 Palestinians and 26 Israelis killed, according to United Nations data. But just in the three weeks since the Oct 7 attack, another 121 West Bank Palestinians have been killed.

Clashes with soldiers have caused most deaths.

However, the actions of Israeli extremists further fuel Palestinian resentment that observers say risks erupting into more armed action.

The Israeli military said it was trying to stem violence and protect Palestinian civilians. "It hurts security here. These ... incidents create more clashes, and it's people who have taken the law into their own hands," a spokesperson said in response to Reuters questions about settler attacks.

'GREAT DANGER'

Settler-related violence is becoming harder to stem with the ongoing Gaza war and the augmented power of far-right politicians, Israeli security experts say.

"There's a great danger (from) extreme right activists in the West Bank," said Lior Akerman, a former officer in Israel's Shin Bet internal security service.

Settlers are using the deployment of soldiers to Gaza and northern Israel, where troops are fighting Lebanese Hezbollah, to wage unimpeded attacks, he said. "The army is now even busier, which allows (settlers) to operate freely.

"They also receive support from representatives of the government ... which makes it difficult for security organisations," he added.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu appointed extreme right-wing ministers, including Ben-Gvir, as part of his cabinet last year to secure another term.

A senior Israeli government official, who declined to be named, said: "Sporadic Palestinian terrorism (in the West Bank) is what makes things more difficult to keep under control."

In a sign the settler incidents are worrying the Israeli security establishment, the defence ministry this week ordered the administrative detention of Ariel Danino, a prominent settler activist on state security grounds, an action usually aimed at Palestinian activists.

'GIVE US GUNS'

Wadi's family is plugged into the local community. He says the family eschews armed action and has watched settler hostilities rise.

He works for a Palestinian government body that monitors soldier and settler violence.

His father, Ibrahim, was a local official who tried to mediate between Israeli and Palestinian authorities to reduce violence and was disliked by radical settlers, Wadi said.

Akerman said settler violence risked provoking armed action by a new generation of Palestinian militants that have emerged in the West Bank. One, The Lion's Den, urged attacks on Israel on Tuesday.

A Reuters witness said that at the funeral that finally took place after the Wadis were killed on Oct. 12, Palestinian gunmen perched on a roof watching proceedings, apparently on the look out for settler violence.

So far there has been no major action as Israel's military chokes Palestinian movement throughout the West Bank and detains hundreds of men.

In Qusra last week, Wadi sat below a poster commemorating his brother and father and scanned his phone for death threats against local Palestinians on Hebrew-language social media pages.

He said he felt surrounded. A fortress-like settlement ringed by a large wall looms opposite Qusra, and two others squat on hills above the village's olive groves.

Abdullah, a local resident who gave only his first name, expressed more anger. "I'm prepared to pick up a gun. If only someone would give us some," he said.

萨尔瓦多国会周三废除了一项将发布帮派信息定为刑事犯罪的法律，执政党领导人宣布在打击犯罪集团的战争中取得胜利。

去年年初，总统纳伊布·布克莱(Nayib Bukele)对这个中美洲小国的极端暴力团伙发起了全面镇压，大幅降低了犯罪率，同时监禁人数猛增，目前已成为世界上最高的国家。

立法者通过了这项改革，目标是任何散布或以其他方式复制犯罪团伙涂鸦“或任何形式的视觉表达”的人，包括 Mara Salvatrucha 及其竞争对手 Barrio 18。

该法律的批评者认为，它不公正地针对记者，他们经常根据显示暴力的图片来获取故事，包括被指控的帮派成员留下的信息，甚至是采访、涂鸦和在社交媒体上分享的音频。

布克莱新思想党高级立法者克里斯蒂安·格瓦拉（Christian Guevara）因推动这项法律而被列入美国“腐败和不民主行为者” 黑名单（俗称“恩格尔名单”）。

尽管萨尔瓦多记者协会 APES 在该法律获得批准后立即将其抨击为“明显的媒体审查企图”，但从未根据该法律进行任何逮捕。

支持该法律的立法者表示，该法律已经达到了目的。

“我们已经赢得了打击帮派的战争，我们可以改变我们的刑事政策，”新思想议员沃尔特·科托(Walter Coto)表示，在场的所有立法者都通过了废除法案。

布克莱在国内享有空前的受欢迎程度，这主要归功于镇压行动，但人权组织认为，该政策无理地限制了基本的正当程序权利，例如进行法律辩护的能力，同时将 73,000 多名犯罪嫌疑人送进监狱。

总统否认了这些虐待行为，并否认了有关他同意与帮派休战的报道。
